text:
Visual: Pours clear copper brown with a smallish 1cm head, a spotty 1mm layer of retention, clusters of very active streams, sticky lacing.

Nose: toffee malt with light citrus hops (lvl-6)-pungency

Attack: soft smooth & crisp

Mid-palate: peach-citrus hop oils, (lvl-3-sweetness), dry metallic, grainy toffee barley malt

Finish: lengthy hopped soft dry bitterness

Summary: Pretty decent, good a good balance of hop and barley grain profile. A tad too metallic for my tastes and the hops are on the dull side.

Bottle in Seattle. Thanks Andrew. Soapy white head, mine poured yeasty (but Andrews poured clear copper-amber). Coppery, bitter malt. Pretty tasty. Mineral undertones. Lots of stone bittering. Body is much sharper and more bitter than Id expected. Nice.

330 mL bottle poured, courtesy of mcberko. Thanks! Remembering one of the best beers from my Vancouver trip being a Four Winds, this is a fun try. Pours an oily copper color with a thin fizz head. Clean malt fronted flavor, with a near perfect balance of hops. Caramel hints, and a subtle bitterness. Creamy body. Good addition to the style here. Very nice

A compact blizzard of foam impossible to navigate through; kilometres of labyrinth and boreal myth. Underneath is a rusted copper core, sunlight inverted into dozing, darkened liquids....... 

Pine cones salivating rich resin. Lonely mountain firs suddenly fructiferous and bearing all manner of grapefruit, velvet pineapple and drunk, wraith-like flowers puffing pollen. Pepper pixies sprinkle crushed bones of their delicately extinct ancestors. A roughness later emerges, a puzzle of pulverised stones and excavation equipment.

The echo of an obliterating bitterness passes through my sinuses while sweet dreams of soft, sticky beatitudes coat the back of my palate. Blessed, sweetened grains and pitted fruits then shrivel into a brief medicinal twang. 

It is its own beer moment.
caramel, dough, amber, hazy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, average carbonation, bitter finish,

Appearance: slightly hazy pale amber with one finger of rocky off-white head, excellent retention and lacing. (5/5) Aroma: bright citrus, stone fruit, pale malt, Resiny pine. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium-light body, moderate carbonation, dry lightly bitter finish. (4/5)

The first whiff of the aroma reminded me of nothing so much as lemon Pledge. Not that it shot a solvent edge - it doesnt, not really - but the citrus is surprisingly bright. Hoppy, but well-balanced with pale malt. A quite enjoyable Pale. (15/20)
amber color. Lots of marmalade and apricots. Well balanced excellent malt backbone. Lots of apricot and marmalade note. Excellent
Mildly carbonated, nice color and clarity. Hoppy taste but not overpowering. Not bad.

330 ml bottle. Clear orange copper, fading off-white foam. Aroma is forest fruity, floral, c-malt. Fruity caramel malt taste, floral citric hop, some spice, beautifully balanced. Softer carbonation, medium bodied, moderately hopped. Very clean and flavourful. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)
On tap at Bitter Tasting Room in Vancouver. An orange amber beer with a moderate white head, and a faint malted nose. Over the gums! A very agreeable balance of hop and malt here. Yassir! 3.6.

Bottle @ Meat & Bread, Vacouver.
 Clean, crisp, hoppy and dry. Nicely refreshing & sessional.
Cool label design. Winner.
Draft - Floral and perfumy. Clear gold with a decent beige head. Flora and perfumy, grassy and some citrus. Dry finish with nice bitterness.
Solid pale ale. Nothing too crazy. Restrained hops. Balanced and flavorful. Enjoyable.

On tap. Pours a hazy copper color with light white head. Aromas of sweet malts and light toffee. Flavors of toasted malts, light caramel and light piney hops. Quite full and chewy for a Pale Ale. Nice.
pint at rogue. Slightly hazy orange with dense white cap and good lacing. Aroma of fruit juice, caramel, and a bit of citrus. Taste is sweet with a subtle bitter tingle. Full flavoured.

Draught @ Vancouver Craft Beer Week Festival 2014, Vancouver, BC
Hoppy, fruity, citrusy and crisp pale ale. Good and balanced.

Deep gold white head. Very floral hops, biscuity malt, not much caramel or citrus in this batch, very clean, not phenolic in the bottle. Recently some English blokes on this site have been complaining about session IPAs being the same as hop-forward golden ales... this is the style theyre talking about. I had a number in my days before joining this site, and this is the first locally brewed beer Ive had that fits that style. Good quality, too. Very glad to see it over here now. Will definitely buy more, doesnt deserve to be flying under the radar, this is a very distinct beer here in the PNW.Im impressed!
Cask d/h with centennial. Big centennial, soft body...bit phenolic...lots of leafy hop but underpinned by sweet malts. Not sure about the regular version but the dry hop works quite nicely.

Copper pour with white head. Aroma is fruity with caramel malts and sweet bread. Minor upfront citrus bitterness followed by bready and caramel malts. Fruity. Slight bitter finish. Fairly heavy on the malts.

great pale ale smell a good bittery hop scent with a good malt character to back it up pours dark unfiltered amber with a med nearly white head great lacing and flavour is a dry hoppy assult with a really good malt flavour so it tastes full
Draught at Craft Beer Market, VancouverHazy amber color with creamy head. Caramelly ale, well bitter, rather dry, but unfortunately with a metallic finish.Not bad, but to be tuned.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2014 Du couleur ambré avec une petite mousse blanche. Larôme du malt et houblon, très fraiche et florale/herbeux. Dabord, le goût est un peu du malt suivi pas un amertume léger mais quand et bien équilibré avec dhoublon floral. Très rafraîchissante et facile à boire mais avec plein du corps.
Sampled at Great Canadian Beer Festival. Typical West Coast-hopped pale ale. Well-balanced, but doesnt take enough risks to qualify as particularly interesting.

Sampled at Great Canadian Beer Festival 2013. Nose of minor orange. Flavor is very fruity, nice hop finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled during VCBW 2013 at the River Rock Casino Resort in Richmond, BC pours a copper color with a small white head that leaves some spotty lacing behind.  Aroma is caramel and light citrus.  Taste is a caramel malty sweetness with a light citrus hop bitterness.  Light to medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  A very well done pale ale that begs to be tasted.

1L growler, pours a hazy golden orange with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out floral hops, biscuity malts, and some light fruity esters. Flavour is quite hoppy for a pale ale, with floral hops, very light fruity esters, and biscuity malts to back. Quite a crisp, dry mouthfeel with very high drinkability. Great stuff.
